**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a court may revise and alter its judgments relating to the custody of minor children when “the circumstances of the parents or the benefit of the children require.”

**G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Norfolk Probate and Family Court** pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, which confer continuing jurisdiction upon this Court to modify custody and visitation orders involving minor children.

**Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdicti.proposition: The child has resided within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts continuously since the entry of that order, satisfying the jurisdictional requirements of the **Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (G.L. c. 209B)** and **G.L. c. 208, § 28A**.

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A**.proposition: The child has resided within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts continuously since the entry of that order, satisfying the jurisdictional requirements of the **Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (G.L. c. 209B)** and **G.L. c. 208, § 28A**.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: A modification may be granted where there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the prior judgment, and where the modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the child** (*Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion is not a modification case and does not discuss the standard for modifying an existing custody or removal order. Instead, it articulates the original removal standard (the ‘real advantage’ test) and explains that ‘upon cause shown’ in the removal statute means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. It nowhere states or applies a requirement of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ since a prior judgment, so it does not support that portion of the proposition, even though it does speak in terms of best interests generally.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A modification may be granted where there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the prior judgment, and where the modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the child** (*Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss modification of custody and removal, but it does not articulate the general standard that a modification may be granted only where there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests. Instead, Mason focuses on interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 30 and clarifies that in joint physical custody removal cases, ‘cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. The ‘material and substantial change’ requirement appears only in a quoted ALI Principles passage and is not adopted as a controlling rule of decision. Thus the case supports the best‑interests component but not the full proposition as phrased.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”}

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s stability, home environment, or relationship with the child may constitute a material change sufficient to revisit custody determinations (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn concerns the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child when making or continuing a custody award. It does not discuss standards for post-judgment modification, nor does it articulate that a change in a parent’s stability, home environment, or relationship with the child constitutes a material change justifying revisiting custody. The case is about how courts must weigh and explain domestic-violence evidence in initial or existing custody determinations, not about what constitutes a material change in circumstances for modification purposes.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s stability, home environment, or relationship with the child may constitute a material change sufficient to revisit custody determinations (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde is an initial divorce and custody decision, not a case about modifying or revisiting a prior custody order based on a material change in circumstances. The opinion discusses best-interests factors and the propriety of sole versus joint custody, but nowhere addresses what qualifies as a ‘material change’ sufficient to reopen an existing custody judgment. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that changes in parental stability, home environment, or relationship with the child constitute such a material change.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The “best interests” standard requires consideration of all factors affecting the child’s welfare, including the child’s relationship with each parent, emotional needs, developmental level, and expressed preferences (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion thoroughly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed, but it does not expressly list or focus on the specific factors recited in the proposition (child’s relationship with each parent, emotional needs, developmental level, expressed preferences). Instead, it frames best interests in terms of a broad, historically rooted standard supplemented by the statutory factors in G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and by considerations of stability and continuity. Thus, while compatible with the proposition at a general level, this case does not clearly state that the best‑interests standard requires the particular factor set claimed.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… This legal principle replaced the notion that children were the property of their parents, and instructed courts to view children as individuals with interests independent of their parents… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The “best interests” standard requires consideration of all factors affecting the child’s welfare, including the child’s relationship with each parent, emotional needs, developmental level, and expressed preferences (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)).
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard in detail and makes clear that the judge must consider a broad range of factors affecting the child’s welfare, including stability, attachments to caretakers and siblings, developmental and special needs, and the resources and capabilities of each potential custodian. While it does not list those factors in a single formulaic sentence, the reasoning repeatedly emphasizes weighing all relevant dimensions of Hugo’s welfare rather than any single factor, which is consistent with the proposition cited. The explicit articulation of the standard as multi-factor and “flexible” aligns with the claimed rule.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … We adhere to our view that in child custody cases the best interests standard mandated by G. L. c. 210, § 3, is ‘a flexible one,’ and the weight to be accorded its several considerations, including the importance of sibling relations, ‘will vary with the circumstances.’”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: When determining whether modification is warranted, the Court must evaluate whether the current arrangement detrimentally affects the child’s emotional health and stability (*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998)).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the custodial rights of an unmarried mother who relocated before paternity was adjudicated. It does discuss the value of stability for the child, but only by quoting Custody of Kali; it does not set out or apply a standard that, when considering modification, the court must specifically evaluate whether the current arrangement detrimentally affects the child’s emotional health and stability. Thus, it does not establish the proposition claimed, and certainly not in the modification context described.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not *558disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child…’).”}

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.proposition: When determining whether modification is warranted, the Court must evaluate whether the current arrangement detrimentally affects the child’s emotional health and stability (*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998)).
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.support_reasoning: Rosenberg v. Merida concerns child support calculation, attachment of assets, and standards for modifying legal custody; it does not articulate a requirement that, in determining whether modification is warranted, the court must evaluate whether the current arrangement detrimentally affects the child’s emotional health and stability. The custody discussion refers generally to the “best interests of the child” standard and the need to weigh all relevant factors, but it does not frame the test in terms of detriment to emotional health and stability. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

*M.C. v. P.C.*, 479 Mass. 246 (2018).proposition: In similar cases, courts have recognized that improved stability and parental availability constitute “changed circumstances” under **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and justify modification (*M.C. v. P.C.*, 479 Mass. 246 (2018); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986)).
*M.C. v. P.C.*, 479 Mass. 246 (2018).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns standards for release of impounded Juvenile Court care-and-protection records and related privilege issues, not modification of custody or support under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The only discussion of Custody of Two Minors is about adverse inferences from a parent's refusal to testify, not about changed circumstances or improved stability/availability as grounds for modification. The case nowhere interprets § 28 or addresses what constitutes a material change in circumstances in domestic relations matters.
*M.C. v. P.C.*, 479 Mass. 246 (2018).relevant_excerpt: “Indeed, as the department is permitted to draw an adverse inference from a parent's decision not to testify, Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 616, 487 N.E.2d 1358 (1986), the parties do not dispute that, without parental testimony at a care and protection proceeding, a parent's chance of retaining custody of a child is, as a practical matter, greatly diminished.… Care and protection proceedings, where a parent's procedural rights do not receive the full protection of criminal adjudications, are not designed to be discovery mechanisms for criminal proceedings.”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.proposition: In similar cases, courts have recognized that improved stability and parental availability constitute “changed circumstances” under **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and justify modification (*M.C. v. P.C.*, 479 Mass. 246 (2018); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986)).
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.support_reasoning: This case is a care-and-protection proceeding under G.L. c. 119, not a G.L. c. 208, § 28 custody-modification case between parents. The opinion does note that the parents made some progress and their home became more stable while the children were in foster care, but that factual observation is not tied to any legal analysis of “changed circumstances” or modification standards under § 28. The holding focuses on current unfitness and clear-and-convincing evidence for permanent commitment to DSS, not on improved stability or parental availability justifying modification of an existing custody judgment.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that, while the children were away from home and in foster care, the parents concentrated on their relationship and were able to make their home environment more stable. He also found that the parents attempted to cooperate with many of the programs made available to them… From the record, the judge determined that, by early 1982, the parents had been making such progress and were benefitting so markedly from the various programs provided them that a consensus was developing among therapists involved toward return of the children to their parents.”
